Award.AwardTitle: Center for Aviation and Automotive Technology Education using Virtual E-School [CA2VES]: A Resource to Meet Technician Workforce Needs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Center for Aviation and Automotive Technology Education Using Virtual E-School is a resource that develops and disseminates E-learning modules with virtual reality and similar high-level visualization/simulation tools for automotive and aviation technician education. The aviation and automotive industries in South Carolina and elsewhere, as well as appropriate ATE Centers, are providing input and validation of the content for the modules being developed and extensively tested. The modules also contain pedagogical strategies and assessments. The primary target audience is the two year college faculty and students in associate degree programs. The virtual teaching environment is also being used to interest high school students and to recruit students from populations underrepresented in technical careers. Since the need for technicians in the industries greatly exceeds the number that can be educated in the two year colleges, the modules provide other venues for learning and recruiting. The Center also provides an online student internship and placement service. The efficacy of high definition modules is compared to that of lower quality that can be viewed on laptops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Aviation and Automotive Technology Education using Virtual E-Schools (CA2VES), located at Clemson University in South Carolina (SC), serves as a state, regional, and national resource for e-learning and digital learning tools research. CA2VES also engages in professional development and creation of advanced curriculum to help educate and prepare a sustainable, multi-skilled technician workforce for various manufacturing industries, including automotive, aviation, and advanced manufacturing across industry sectors in the United States (US). CA2VES continues to identify and meet the needs of technician education faculty and students to reach and serve underrepresented students with innovative research, digital learning tools, and curriculum applications.

CA2VES is a strong, vibrant, proactive partnership between Clemson University and the Clemson University Center for Workforce Development (CUCWD); the SC ATE National Center via SCATE, Inc.; Florence-Darlington Technical College; Greenville Technical College; and Spartanburg Community College. Additionally, CA2VES currently partners and collaborates with 5 NSF ATE Centers--AMTEC, CAAT, CARCAM, FLATE, and SpaceTEC; all 16 SC 2-year colleges and their high school partners; and the SC automotive and aviation industry. The CA2VES e-learning modules and curriculum developed to date support a wide range of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) interests and technician education career pathways.

Accomplishments under the current NSF funding include: (1) an innovative, high-impact personalized learning “Virtual E-School” curriculum model for educating 2-year college students and industry employees in aviation and automotive manufacturing technology; (2) an increased pool of highly-skilled, work-ready technicians for immediate transition into industry; (3) development of targeted recruiting resources to attract and retain underrepresented groups to A2 technology; (4) development of the Virtual E-School as a standard pedagogical tool; and (5) creation of a national collaborative venture among universities, 2-year colleges, high schools, and key industries.

Accomplishments to date:

Digital Learning Tools (DLTs) to Expand Technician Education Capacity at 2-year Colleges

  • Development of over 30 virtual reality tools and simulations which have been integrated into automotive, aviation, and other general technician education curricula.
  • Development of over 50 advanced e-learning modules for technician education providing innovative curriculum
  • Evaluation of pedagogical effectiveness through a pilot study (Spring 2012), analysis of results of pilot sites (5 in 2013), and a large-scale study (ongoing) to determine impact and educational effectiveness of DLTs.

Increasing Access and Supporting Recruitment for Students in Technician Education Programs

  • Development and distribution of DLTs, lessons, and materials to expose students and build interest in STEM fields, technician education, and 2-year college programs:

  • Development of a state-of-the-art dissemination portal, www.educateworkforce.com, offers basic and advanced DLTs focusing on the needs of technician education programs.
